moves.1. d4 f5: A Dutch defence, may be a brave choice to play against Nisipeanu.
moves.2. g3 g6 3. Bg2 Bg7 4. Nf3 Nh6: Usually the Dutch will play ..Nf6 but here Black may be like to maximalized his Bishop attacking range and also manuevering the Knight to Nf7 later.
moves.5. h4: Regular setup is White doing castling (O-O), but Nisipeanu choose to immediately start the Kingside attack.Perhaps due to White get more easy to develop his extra Bishop while Black's queenside are harder.
moves.5... Nf7 6. h5 e6 7. Nc3 d5 8. g4: A risky move but maintain White's forcing initiative.
moves.10... Bxh8 11. Nh2: White can take back the -1 pawn easily.
moves.11... c5 12. dxc5 g3 13. fxg3 Qc7 14. Qd: Black get back the pawn and targeting the lose space in White's Kingside.
moves.16. Qh6:
White decide to sacrifice a Bishop here? 
Can White sole Queen give trouble to Black's King?
moves.16... Nf7 17. Qxg6 Qg1+: 17...Bxc3+ 18.bxc3 Qxc3+ 19.Kf1 Qxa1 20.Qg8+, Black did not choose this line perhaps due to fear of White's active piece.
moves.18. Nf1 Qxg2: And now Black get his extra bishop. But again his inactive piece may be compensate to this.
moves.19. Bg5: Which is now quite a mistake move,  19.Qg8+ Ke7 20.Qxc8 And yet White gains back a "plus" score, but Nisipeanu choose more intimidate line.
moves.19... Kf8 20. O-O-O Nc6: Black begin to activate his "sleeping" pieces. If  20...Bxc3 21.bxc3 Qe4 22.Bh6+ Ke7 still many balance play by Black.
moves.21. Ne3: And this give White the very TEMPO he need it.
moves.24... exd5: And a mistake, Kd6 will hold the game, but now White can execute a force line.  24...Kd6 (..Kd7 fall into the same mate pattern.) 25.Qe4 exd5 26.Qxd5+ Ke7
